## Import external data {.unnumbered} ::: {.cell hash='wrangling4_cache/html/setup_29acbea771ca1366160309358d47d0c7'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load required packages library(dplyr) require(Hmisc) ``` ::: When dealing with data analysis in R, it's common to need to import external data. This tutorial will walk you through importing data in different formats. ### CSV format data CSV stands for "Comma-Separated Values" and it's a widely used format for data. We'll be looking at the "Employee Salaries - 2017" dataset, which contains salary information for permanent employees of Montgomery County in 2017. ::: column-margin [Employee Salaries - 2017 data](https://data.amerigeoss.org/it/dataset/employee-salaries-2017/resource/c6abf511-62fb-457d-b90b-e0d11a5e4ab8) ::: ::: callout-tip We'll be loading the `Employee_Salaries_-_2017.csv` dataset into R from its saved location at `Data/wrangling/`. Do note, the directory path might vary for you based on where you've stored the downloaded data. ::: ::: {.cell hash='wrangling4_cache/html/load_7af21a77696d764d93d38fad057bbb7d'} ```{.r .cell-code} data.download <- read.csv("Data/wrangling/Employee_Salaries_-_2017.csv") ``` ::: Here, the `read.csv` function reads the data from the CSV file and stores it in a variable called `data.download`. To understand the structure of our dataset, We can see the number of rows and columns and the names of the columns/variables as follows: ::: {.cell hash='wrangling4_cache/html/load1_e4c31cbc83f98c7d1497fb3c28ec6420'} ```{.r .cell-code} dim(data.download) # check dimension / row / column numbers #> [1] 9398 12 nrow(data.download) # check row numbers #> [1] 9398 names(data.download) # check column names #> [1] "Full.Name" "Gender" #> [3] "Current.Annual.Salary" "X2017.Gross.Pay.Received" #> [5] "X2017.Overtime.Pay" "Department" #> [7] "Department.Name" "Division" #> [9] "Assignment.Category" "Employee.Position.Title" #> [11] "Position.Under.Filled" "Date.First.Hired" ``` ::: ::: callout-tip `head` shows the first 6 elements of an object, giving you a sneak peek into the data you're dealing with, while `tail` shows the last 6 elements. ::: We can see the first see six rows of the dataset as follows: ::: {.cell hash='wrangling4_cache/html/load2_62d932c668e5bdaf7038ae1fa65d3ea8'} ```{.r .cell-code} head(data.download) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: Next, for learning purposes, let's artificially assign all male genders in our dataset as missing: ::: {.cell hash='wrangling4_cache/html/load3_503fe314923303c8f5ae64e92285d3ac'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Assigning male gender as missing data.download$Gender[data.download$Gender == "M"] <- NA head(data.download) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: This chunk sets the Gender column's value to NA (missing) wherever the gender is "M". This is a form of data manipulation, sometimes used to handle missing or incorrect data. If you want to work with datasets that exclude any missing values: ::: callout-tip `na.omit` and `complete.cases` are useful functions to to create datasets with non-NA values ::: ::: {.cell hash='wrangling4_cache/html/load4_6d364c5090331a0861a81f09df57270e'} ```{.r .cell-code} # deleting/dropping missing components data.download2 <- na.omit(data.download) head(data.download2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} dim(data.download2) #> [1] 3806 12 ``` ::: Here, na.omit is used to remove rows with any missing values. This can be essential when preparing data for certain analyses. Alternatively, we could have selected only females to drop all males: ::: {.cell hash='wrangling4_cache/html/load5_4f07337b77657a1d630d1d9828f287a5'} ```{.r .cell-code} data.download3 <- filter(data.download, Gender != "M") head(data.download3) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: And to check the size of this new dataset: ::: {.cell hash='wrangling4_cache/html/load6_1b4a05f5e251f20e810fb679b7e928bb'} ```{.r .cell-code} # new dimension / row / column numbers dim(data.download3) #> [1] 3806 12 ``` ::: ### SAS format data ::: callout-tip SAS is another data format, commonly used in professional statistics and analytics. ::: Let's explore importing a SAS dataset. We download a SAS formatted dataset from the CDC website. ::: {.cell hash='wrangling4_cache/html/sas_0a7fe2a5a2dc7f83bc05700371724f4c'} ```{.r .cell-code} NHANES1516data <- sasxport.get("https://wwwn.cdc.gov/Nchs/Nhanes/2015-2016/DEMO_I.XPT") #> Processing SAS dataset DEMO_I .. dim(NHANES1516data) # check dimension / row / column numbers #> [1] 9971 47 nrow(NHANES1516data) # check row numbers #> [1] 9971 names(NHANES1516data)[1:10] # check first 10 names #> [1] "seqn" "sddsrvyr" "ridstatr" "riagendr" "ridageyr" "ridagemn" #> [7] "ridreth1" "ridreth3" "ridexmon" "ridexagm" ``` ::: The `sasxport.get` function retrieves the SAS dataset. The following lines, just like before, help understand its structure. To analyze some of the data: ::: {.cell hash='wrangling4_cache/html/sas2_908b8583295a2d73e5acd66cbceea884'} ```{.r .cell-code} table(NHANES1516data$riagendr) # tabulating gender variable #> #> 1 2 #> 4892 5079 ``` ::: ::: column-margin Verify these numbers from [CDC website](https://wwwn.cdc.gov/Nchs/Nhanes/2015-2016/DEMO_I.htm#RIAGENDR) ::: This code creates a frequency table of the `riagendr` variable, which represents gender. ### Saving working dataset ::: callout-tip Once you've made modifications or conducted some preliminary analysis, it's important to save your dataset. We can save the dataset in a different format, e.g., CSV, txt, or even R, SAS or other formats. ::: We can save our working dataset in different formats. Say, we want to save our `NHANES1516data` dataset in `csv` format. We can use the `write.csv()` command: ::: {.cell hash='wrangling4_cache/html/savecsv_8dfe862bf472c83a4c9fdd175d1f376e'} ```{.r .cell-code} write.csv(NHANES1516data, "Data/wrangling/NHANES1516.csv", row.names = FALSE) ``` ::: We can also save the dataset in `R` format: ::: {.cell hash='wrangling4_cache/html/saveR_b77203692a7b70fd12801a8e39089848'} ```{.r .cell-code} save(NHANES1516data, file = "Data/wrangling/NHANES1516.RData") ``` :::
